definitions: make a complete list of items organized in a systematic way
record and organize information about things into an ordered system
examples: The librarian will catalogue all the new books this week
Scientists catalogue every species they discover in the rainforest
Museums carefully catalogue their artifacts with detailed descriptions and photos
The company needs to catalogue its inventory before the audit

definitions: cause or speed up a chemical reaction by acting as a catalyst
cause an important event or change to happen more quickly than usual
examples: Enzymes catalyze reactions in our bodies every second
The platinum surface will catalyze the hydrogen and oxygen reaction
Her speech catalyzed a movement for social justice nationwide
The economic crisis catalyzed major reforms in banking regulations

definitions: throw or launch something or someone forward with great force suddenly
move suddenly from a lower position to a much higher one very quickly
examples: The explosion catapulted debris across the entire parking lot
The kids catapulted water balloons over the fence yesterday
The viral video catapulted the singer to international fame overnight
One bestselling novel catapulted her from unknown writer to celebrity

definitions: arrange things into groups based on what type they are or their characteristics
put people or things into categories according to shared qualities or features
examples: Scientists categorize animals based on their physical characteristics and DNA
The library categorizes books by subject matter and genre
Psychologists categorize personality types using various testing methods and criteria
The store categorizes products to make shopping easier for customers

definitions: provide food and drinks for an event or gathering professionally
provide what is wanted or needed by a particular person or group
examples: They cater weddings and corporate events throughout the city
Who will cater the company's annual holiday party this year
This store caters to customers who want organic products only
The new gym caters specifically to senior citizens' fitness needs

definitions: pretend to be someone else online to trick someone into a romantic relationship
examples: She discovered her online boyfriend was catfishing her for months
Scammers often catfish lonely people on dating apps for money

definitions: warn someone about possible danger or problems that might happen
examples: The doctor cautioned her about the medicine's side effects
Police caution drivers to slow down during the storm

definitions: make the loud harsh cry that crows and similar birds make
examples: The crows cawed loudly outside my window every morning
A raven cawed from the top of the old oak tree

definitions: give up power or control of something to another person or country
examples: The country was forced to cede territory after losing the war
The CEO reluctantly ceded control of the company to investors

definitions: join things together using cement or concrete material that hardens
make a relationship agreement or position much stronger and more certain
examples: Workers will cement the bricks together to build the wall
The contractor cemented the posts firmly into the ground yesterday
This partnership will cement our position as market leaders globally
Their shared experiences cemented their friendship for life

definitions: remove parts of books films or letters that are considered offensive or harmful
officially examine and suppress unacceptable parts of books newspapers films or communications
examples: The government censors all movies before they're shown in theaters
They had to censor several scenes to get a PG rating
Military officials censor soldiers' letters during wartime for security reasons
Some countries censor internet content to control what citizens see

definitions: express severe disapproval of someone or something especially in a formal statement
examples: Congress voted to censure the senator for unethical behavior
The medical board censured the doctor for negligence

definitions: bring activities or organizations together to be controlled from one main place
examples: The company decided to centralize all purchasing decisions at headquarters
Many governments centralize education policy at the national level

definitions: place something in or at the center or middle position of something
have something as the main subject of attention interest or activity
examples: Centre the picture on the wall before hanging it up
The designer centred the logo in the middle of the page
The discussion centred on finding solutions to climate change
Her research centres around childhood development and learning

definitions: officially confirm that something is true correct or meets required standards
officially recognize that someone has successfully completed training and has necessary qualifications
examples: The inspector must certify that the building meets safety codes
A doctor needs to certify that you're fit to work
The board will certify new teachers after they pass all exams
This program certifies technicians in computer network administration

definitions: tease someone in a friendly way about something
examples: His friends chaff him about his new haircut constantly
The teammates chaff each other during practice to stay relaxed

definitions: make someone feel disappointed upset or embarrassed about something that happened
examples: It chagrined him to admit he had been completely wrong
Her careless mistakes chagrined her in front of the boss

definitions: write or draw something using a piece of chalk
consider that something is caused by a particular thing or reason
examples: The teacher chalked the equation on the blackboard
Children love to chalk colorful pictures on the sidewalk
We can chalk up his bad mood to lack of sleep
They chalked their success to years of hard work

definitions: bite or chew something noisily and repeatedly showing impatience or eagerness
examples: The horse champed at its bit waiting to start racing
He champed on his cigar while reading the newspaper

definitions: sing religious songs or prayers using only a few notes repeated many times
repeat words or phrases continuously in a loud rhythmic way especially in groups
examples: Monks chant prayers in the monastery every morning at dawn
The choir will chant hymns during the religious ceremony tonight
Protesters chanted slogans outside the government building all day
Fans chanted the player's name until he came back out

definitions: become cracked rough and sore especially skin from cold wind or dryness
examples: Cold winter winds chap my lips if I don't use balm
Working outside all day chapped his hands terribly

definitions: go with and supervise young people at social events to ensure proper behavior
examples: Parents volunteer to chaperone the school dance every year
She will chaperone the field trip to the museum tomorrow

definitions: burn something so that its surface becomes black but not completely destroyed
work as a cleaner in someone's house especially in past times
examples: The flames charred the outside of the steak perfectly
Lightning charred the tree trunk but didn't destroy it completely
She used to char for wealthy families in the neighborhood
My grandmother would char houses to earn extra money

definitions: describe the main features or qualities of someone or something
be a typical or main quality that makes something different from others
examples: The report characterises the economy as unstable but recovering
Critics characterise her writing style as bold and innovative
Patience and kindness characterise all of her interactions with students
Dark clouds and strong winds characterise the approaching storm

definitions: criticize or punish someone severely for doing something wrong
examples: The coach chastised the team for their poor performance
Her mother chastised her for coming home so late

definitions: talk quickly continuously about things that are not important
make a series of short high sounds quickly like teeth or machines
examples: The students chattered excitedly about their weekend plans
She tends to chatter nervously when meeting new people
His teeth chattered from the freezing cold weather
Monkeys chattered loudly in the trees above us

definitions: drive a car for someone as a job especially for rich or important people
examples: He chauffeurs executives to meetings around the city daily
She chauffeured the bride and groom to their reception

definitions: mark something with a pattern of squares in two different colors
examine something carefully to make sure it is correct or accurate
examples: The fabric was checkered with red and white squares
The racing flag is checkered with black and white
Please checker your work before submitting the final report
Someone needs to checker these figures for accuracy

definitions: put the opponent's king in a position where it cannot escape being captured in chess
defeat someone completely by clever planning so they cannot avoid losing
examples: She checkmated her opponent in just fifteen moves
The chess master checkmated three players simultaneously
The prosecutor checkmated the defense with surprise evidence
Their business strategy checkmated all their competitors

definitions: make a payment using a written order to a bank to pay money
examples: She prefers to cheque her monthly rent instead of paying cash
Can you cheque the amount to my business account please

definitions: love protect and care for someone or something that is important to you
keep a hope memory or pleasant feeling in your mind for a long time
examples: Parents cherish their children above everything else in life
She cherishes the antique necklace her grandmother gave her
He cherishes memories of summers spent at his grandparents' farm
They cherish the hope of being reunited with family soon

definitions: make something cold or cool it down to a low temperature
relax completely and become calm especially with friends in informal situations
examples: Chill the wine in the refrigerator before serving tonight
The autumn air chilled us as we walked home
Let's just chill at home and watch movies tonight
You need to chill out and stop worrying so much

definitions: make clear ringing sounds like bells especially to mark time
join a conversation by adding a comment especially to agree with others
examples: The church bells chime every hour throughout the day
The grandfather clock chimed midnight as we celebrated
She chimed in with her own ideas during the meeting
Everyone chimed in to wish him happy birthday

definitions: make short high sounds like small birds or insects do
examples: Birds chirp outside my window every morning at sunrise
The baby sparrows chirped constantly asking for food

definitions: cut or shape wood stone or metal using a chisel tool
cheat someone out of money by being dishonest in small ways
examples: The sculptor chiseled the marble into a beautiful statue
He carefully chiseled his initials into the wooden bench
The contractor tried to chisel them out of their deposit
Don't let him chisel you on the price

definitions: prevent a wheel or vehicle from moving by putting a wedge against it
examples: Always chock the airplane wheels before starting maintenance work
They chocked the truck's wheels while loading heavy equipment

definitions: be unable to breathe because something is blocking your throat or there's no air
fail to perform well because of nervousness in an important situation
examples: He started to choke on a piece of meat during dinner
Smoke from the fire made everyone choke and cough
The tennis player choked in the final match of the tournament
Don't choke during your presentation tomorrow

definitions: play several musical notes together at the same time to create harmony
examples: She chorded beautifully on the piano during the concert
The guitarist chorded along with the singer's melody

definitions: design and arrange the movements and steps for dancers in a performance
examples: She choreographed the entire ballet in just three weeks
They hired someone to choreograph their wedding dance

definitions: give a baby its name at a Christian religious ceremony
use something for the first time or give it a name informally
examples: They will christen their daughter Emma at the church Sunday
The priest christened the baby in front of family
Let's christen the new boat with a sailing trip today
We christened our vacation home 'Sandy Shores'

definitions: cover metal with a thin layer of chromium to make it shiny
examples: The factory chromes motorcycle parts to prevent rust
They chromed the car bumpers for a classic look

definitions: throw something carelessly or get rid of something you don't want
touch someone gently under the chin in an affectionate way
examples: Chuck those old magazines in the recycling bin please
He chucked his jacket on the chair and sat down
Grandma always chucks the baby under the chin lovingly
He chucked her chin playfully before leaving

definitions: stir or mix something vigorously and continuously especially to make butter
move about violently like water that is disturbed or agitated
examples: Farmers used to churn milk by hand to make butter
The machine churns ice cream until it's perfectly smooth
Storm waves churned the ocean into white foam
My stomach churned with anxiety before the interview

definitions: slide or drop quickly down a chute or steep narrow passage
examples: The packages chute down to the warehouse floor below
Skiers chute down the steep mountain slope at high speed

definitions: put a message into secret code so others cannot read it
do arithmetic calculations or work out problems using numbers
examples: Spies cipher their messages before sending them to headquarters
The military ciphered all communications during the war
Students learning to cipher basic math problems in class
Merchants had to cipher quickly to calculate prices

definitions: move continuously through a closed system or area going around in circles
pass from person to person or place to place spreading information or objects
examples: Blood circulates through our bodies pumping from the heart
Cool air circulates through the building's ventilation system
Please circulate this memo to all department heads today
Rumors about layoffs circulated quickly through the office

definitions: travel all the way around something especially the world by ship or aircraft
examples: Magellan's crew was first to circumnavigate the globe successfully
They plan to circumnavigate Australia in their yacht

definitions: find a way around an obstacle problem or rule without directly confronting it
avoid something especially a rule or law by finding a clever way around it
examples: Hackers try to circumvent security systems to access data
The road was blocked so we circumvented through side streets
Some companies circumvent tax laws through offshore accounts
Students shouldn't circumvent the school's internet filters
